message_1: A Ferris wheel with a radius of 20 meters makes one complete revolution every 40 seconds. If the bottom of the Ferris wheel is 5 meters above the ground, write an equation to represent the height of a passenger on the Ferris wheel as a function of time, and determine the height of a passenger after 15 seconds.
message_2:
To find the height of a passenger on the Ferris wheel as a function of time, we can use the equation:

h(t) = R * sin(ωt + φ) + k

where:
h(t) is the height of the passenger at time t,
R is the radius of the Ferris wheel (20 meters),
ω is the angular velocity (in radians per second),
t is the time (in seconds),
φ is the phase shift (in radians), and
k is the vertical shift (in meters).

Since the Ferris wheel makes one complete revolution every 40 seconds, its angular velocity ω can be calculated as:

ω = 2π / T
where T is the period (40 seconds).

ω = 2π / 40 = π / 20 radians per second

The bottom of the Ferris wheel is 5 meters above the ground, so the vertical shift k is:

k = R + 5 = 20 + 5 = 25 meters

Since the passenger starts at the bottom of the Ferris wheel, the phase shift φ is:

φ = -π / 2 radians

Now we can write the equation for the height of a passenger on the Ferris wheel as a function of time:

h(t) = 20 * sin(π/20 * t - π/2) + 25

To find the height of a passenger after 15 seconds, we can plug t = 15 into the equation:

h(15) = 20 * sin(π/20 * 15 - π/2) + 25

h(15) ≈ 20 * sin(3π/4) + 25 ≈ 20 * 0.7071 + 25 ≈ 14.14 + 25 ≈ 39.14 meters

So, after 15 seconds, the height of a passenger is approximately 39.14 meters above the ground.
